title: HTML Project Structure
subject: HTML
theory:
# Project Structure

As your website grows, you can't keep all files in one folder. You need an organized directory structure.

## Standard Structure

```
/my-website
  ├── index.html       (Homepage)
  ├── about.html
  ├── /css
  │    └── style.css
  ├── /js
  │    └── app.js
  └── /images
       ├── logo.png
       └── banner.jpg
```

## 1. `index.html`
Web servers are configured to look for a file named `index.html` by default when a user visits a domain (e.g., `www.example.com`). This must be your homepage.

## 2. Folder Organization
*   **css/**: Stylesheets.
*   **js/** or **scripts/**: JavaScript files.
*   **images/** or **assets/**: Media files.

## 3. Referencing Files (Paths)
When files are in folders, use relative paths.

*   From `index.html` to logo: `src="images/logo.png"`
*   From `style.css` to `index.html`: `../index.html` (`..` means go up one level).

common_mistakes.correction: Don't use spaces or uppercase letters in filenames. URLs are sensitive.
Moving a file breaks all links pointing to it. Plan structure early.

interview_questions.question: Why is the main file named index.html?
interview_questions.answer: Web servers (Apache/Nginx) are configured to automatically serve 'index.html' if a user requests a directory URL (like example.com/) instead of a specific file.

practice_problems.problem: Write the path to link an image 'cat.jpg' inside 'images' folder, from a file inside 'pages' folder.

real_world_use_cases.description: When deploying to Netlify or Vercel, the build system looks specifically for an index.html at the root (or publish directory) to start the site.

summary: A clean project structure is the sign of a professional. Grouping assets into folders like /css, /js, and /images keeps the project manageable. Understanding relative paths (../) is essential for linking these files together.
